Expectation1: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation1: A brief encounter in the corridor leads to a simple hello and smile.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Story: I stepped out of my apartment, research notes in hand, ready to head to my lab and update the latest batch of results. As I locked my door, Mrs. Kim from next door appeared in the corridor, her arms full of groceries. She smiled warmly, expecting the usual friendly hello and perhaps a quick chat. I knew she valued these small exchanges; it was part of being a good neighbor, something I prided myself on. But my mind was already racing with the data I needed to log—details still fresh, nuances I didn’t want to lose. The logs could technically wait, but accuracy mattered, and I always tried to document findings while they were clear in my mind. I felt the tug between pausing for a neighborly moment and rushing off to capture my research precisely. My smile faltered as I weighed the expectations: the warmth of community versus the integrity of my work. I hesitated, caught between the two roles, unsure which demand to meet first.
